bioghist.p: Robert Milton Speer (1838-1890) was a Democratic member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Pennsylvania. He attended Cassville Academy, taught school, studied law, and was admitted to the bar in 1859. He was elected assistant clerk of the Pennsylvania State House of Representatives in 1863. Speer served in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1871-1875. He was not a candidate for renomination in 1874. He resumed the practice of law and in 1876 became one of the proprietors of the Huntingdon Monitor. He was an unsuccessful candidate for election in 1880 to the Forty-seventh Congress. His wife was Martha Ellen McMurtrie.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of letters to Robert Milton Speer. The letters are from clients and those seeking legal assistance, supporters of his political career, and family members. Subjects include legal matters and the war; the 1868 presidential election; Speer's election to Congress and party politics; and requests for legal aid or favors. The collection includes letters of E. S. McMurtrie, D. E. McMurtrie, J. North, and C. C. North (E. S. McMurtrie was in partnership with Speer; the McMurtries and Norths were Speer's in-laws). Letters from family members regard family estate matters that Speer handled for them and his political career and party politics.
